Posts.Title: Letrozole and the blues!

Posts.Content: Owww dminnimouse, I feel for you, we are our own worst enemy at times like this, we will chase thoughts around and around in our head - and end up completely draining ourselves emotionally, mentally and physically.  You will be the same person you were yesterday, that you are today and will be tomorrow, only you'll have the added knowledge of knowing where you are - whether you 'looked at the ride' and watched it go off without you, I hope this will be the case.  If it's not, then you are not alone, there is a cue of ladies getting their tickets for the ride (treatment) - remember though, for you to get on so many of us have had to get off the other side (had treatment). I had a lumpectomy and radiation therapy treatment, followed by hormone treatment for the next 5 years - I give Thanks to God I am now off the ride, although, mentally it is taking a lot for me to believe this, every twinge or pain my mind is back racing (its the mind again, such a cruel place.    dminnimouse, it is in our nature to worry - please try not to hold onto this - when you get a 'thought', push it away, tell yourself 'no, no, I'm not thinking about this, do something, distract yourself, sing a song, count, phone some, anything - just try and get it out of your mind. Thinking of you and sending you a big {{{{{{{{{Hug}}}}}}}}

Posts.Title: AIs and acupuncture

Posts.Content: I have had my operation, radiotherapy and am now on letrozole for 5 years.  I had a Wide Local Excision and was told the lymph nodes were negative, the cancer was stage 1 and all looks good, with good clear margins. I started to think I could try and get some normality back in to my life, then.... Tonight, I looked at my pathology report and now I'm worried.... Could anyone please tell me what you think this might mean.... grade 1 (T2 P2 M1) <<<< Could anyone tell me what this means, I am taking M1 to mean it has metastasised?   I have been told all is good and there was no mention of metastasis ?? There are other parts to the report, but, this part read like this.... Left breast side local excision. - Breast tissue shows infiltration by invasive ductal carcinoma, grade 1 (T2 P2 M1) 19mm in diameter. - Intermediate grade comedo DCIS is present within the tumour. - Malignant calcifications are seen. - Background breast is unremarkable. - The margins appear clear by more than 5mm I had been told all is good and there was no mention of metastasis ??  Any help please.

Posts.Title: ANY BC LADIES IN STOCKKORT?

Posts.Content: Good Evening/Morning Baki, I was referred to Professor Ellis by my surgeon.  Professor Ellis is a lovely kind gentleman that puts you at ease straight away, he listens to you, does not rush you and is very approachable.  When you are on this treadmill and don't really know where you are going or what you are doing it is good to have advise on everything.  After all my research, I was thinking I would need "Bisphosphonates" - I felt at easy to ask him if I should be having these, the response was, an hour later I was having a bone density scan, the results of my scan showed my bones look good for my age and therefore not required. I will be truthful, when I was leaving, I did feel a little unsure; this was down to myself thinking 'I would be needing some kind of treatment'. This said, I would have no hesitation in making contact should I have any concerns. If we don't feel comfortable with the people caring for us, I personally think this has a knock on effect both treatment wise and mentally.   You could always book and see how you get on. Hope I've helped a little.

Posts.Title: Had my op

Posts.Content: Hello, funny you posting this.  I am on letrozole and have taken it now for '6 months' (I had to work that out and now I'm in shock to think I've been on it for 6 months!!!).  Well, I had the cold/flu/lurgey from hell for the whole month of January.  I did have a bad cough at first and slowly it went, I was left with not a cough, but a type of (sorry now this is gross to say, but, it may help).. I would have out of no where a type of very, very small amount of mucus/phlegm that would just come to the back of my throat - however, no matter how hard I tried I could hardly ever manage to 'cough it up' and on the odd times I did, it was clear, but, very, very sticky (thick to I suppose). 5 weeks or so on and I am still getting it, also, find I get it more when I go to speak it sort of stops me from speaking (could be a good thing), it stops me speaking till I clear my throat with a little cough type of thing (I don't know how to spell what I'd like to say).  I have noticed that one of the side effects can be 'dryness of mucous membranes' - well if they are drying up, I suppose it would make the mucous thicker. I'm now trying to drink more (some) water. Hope this helps - All the best and let us know how you get on xxxx

Posts.Title: Bit Scared and a Lot Angry

Posts.Content: Dearest LB9, Firstly, welcome to the group that none of us want to join.  The ladies and guys on this site are amazing and have a wealth of information. Please stop worrying, please, it really won't help you, it will just drain you and make you feel worse.  I am sorry I can't answer about the BRCA2 gene type of BC, however there are lots of ladies on here that will be able to give you advice.  What I can say, is 'it is 'not' it for you!!!  Worse case scenario, if it is anything untoward, so, so much can be done, so much has changed in recent years, treatments are improving all the time. I would say, as hard as this is, put it out of your mind as best as you can until you go to the Breast Clinic, before you start thinking all the things that I know you are, wait until you actually know something, it really might be nothing, the time of the month tenderness, a cyst, so many different reasons.  You are the same person you was last week, yesterday, today and tomorrow and next week, please don't drive yourself mad worrying. You have done something about this which is good, you have gone to your doctors, you will see the breast clinic team, you have joined this group, so until your appointment try hard to put it out of your mind.  You could try some meditation or mindfulness - there are a lot of apps that are good, these will help you, especially the sleep ones.  I found them really helpful, any time I started to get myself worked up I would listen to one of them and I will say they did help. Please keep posting on here, ask any questions you want to, we are a friendly bunch.  I am sure others will be along to guide you.   With Love and Hugs xx
Posts.Title: Worried I might have Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: I don't want my reply to cause any panic or upset, I'd like to see others responses, what they know, have had or know of. We are all in this together and I believe the more we know and are clear about the better it is for all of us.... Hello Feb59, I am glad I found your post. I had this very discussion with a friend today, she is past menopause and was prescribed tamoxifen due to slight thinning of bones, apparently tamoxifen can help with this (maybe we have found one advantage for it?). Anyway, she does not know what to do about taking the Tamoxifen, I asked the reason why..... She is of the belief Tamoxifen and Letrozole are prescribed with the view of preventing a 'reoccurrence' of Breast Cancer, only breast cancer not any others. (me reply, thats's brilliant for starters then).   She added that when she asked her GP about side effects of Tamoxifen 'causing' uterus cancer' the GP tried to pass this off quickly and when pushed the GP did say that it can cause this.   I don't know percentages - what it did open my eyes to, was I thought (my own doing I suppose in the mixed up mind of my mind) I thought I was taking Letrozole to prevent both 'reoccurrence and secondaries' - I was told it is to prevent reoccurrence, but this mind of mine took that to mean secondaries too. So, I understand its to stop reoccurrence - but could it cause secondaries ie uterus cancer? Has anyone heard if Letrozole can cause/trigger Uterus cancer?  My minefield is getting more mines added to it arrgghhh  I think it is good we can come on hear and be able to discuss all of this kind of information and share knowledge, it helps us all xxxxx (Hoping my post makes sense, feel like I've waffled). xxx

Posts.Content: Dear Princess Betty, I've not read all your posts just yet, I am a little short on time along with replying from my mobile..... I am so sorry you have had to experience this, I have tried no end to get the word out there for this amazing treatment.  It is so unfair and so cruel to allow us people going through this to be denied approved treatment, treatment that could be all over and done with in one operation (subject to clear margins, etc - this is the same with all operations).  To avoid weeks of daily radiotherapy - and all because there are issues with who's faces get put out so to speak!!! Firstly, it is fantastic that you have had the courage and foresight to ask for this treatment and that you would be prepared to travel for this treatment, yet it is still not available to you!!!! This only goes to reiterate and confirm we are being denied such an amazing treatment!!!  Moving forward, in answer to your questions... I too found out about Targit IORT (Inter-operative radiotherapy treatment) #Targit #IORT from doing my own research. From my initial contact late on a Thursday afternoon, the coming Monday I was on a train travelling to have various tests etc. Returning for further tests on the Thursday, staying overnight to have my operation (Lumpectomy and Radiotherapy) on the Friday.  Saturday lunchtime I was travelling home. Follow up appointments, etc are as you say 'pay as you go'. Time from contact to surgery was just over a week.  I hope this helps, please feel free to message me if you need any more information. Sending Love and Hugs xxxx

Posts.Content: Princess Betty,  I should say...  'Welcome You to the Forum' as we all say, a group that none of us wanted to join.  This said, the people on this site are fantastic, really kind, caring and so, so helpful, day or night there is normally one of the Fruit Loops about. I have accepted your friends request, you can send private messages via the email/envelope button towards the top right of the page, near the 'log in' area. Once the operation is done you have follow up's appointments, these are 'pay as you go' as you say.   Hormone treatment, Letrozole is prescribed on the NHS via your doctor, normally on a monthly repeat prescription. In case you aren't made aware of this, all your prescriptions will be free of charge from the NHS for the next 5 years (I think it is 5 years). Depending how urgent urgent is, I would imagine you would go straight to A&E.  Saying this, I can't see what could happen that is urgent as such, if there was anything urgent causing you concern you would phone the PA/Secretary or BC Nurse and they would talk you through this and arrange for you to see Consultant if need be.   I really hope it is the same surgeon I am with, he is wonderful, truly a wonderful, kind, caring man - Please give him my best regards. If you need any other advice or need to talk please message me. Don't panic - one step at a time - You can do this. Gail, xx

Posts.Content: Owwwww wowwww Happybird - wow - wow - wow This is an inspirational photo.  How blessed you are to live by the sea.  I love the sea, open air, beaches and wind (not that type haha).   My star sign is Cancer (hmmm) the Crab (maybe this is why I love the sea and the beach). This view whilst walking will certainly get you 'walking back to happiness'. I have gone out three times this week.  It took me forever to get myself up off the settee, so nearly didn't do it.  Just before I go out I set my phone alarm for 15 minutes (then thought oww 15 mins there (not sure yet) and 15 mins back - this will be 'half an hour' am I ready for this.  So, I goe out and walk through the side walkway leading towards a long road with houses on (I've walked this maybe 4 times in my entire time of living around here, its just somewhere you don't walk unless you live on the road, you always tend to drive down this road). So, I considered this (silly or not I don't feel safe out alone - when I've said this to other half in the past, he jokes (hmmm) look in the mirror, you'll be safe :o  ) Hence why my walks are 'secret' at the moment and if/when I build up some stamina along with loose some weight I will then share! For now, this is the start of 'my time'. Anyway how bad is this, I'm walking away at a steady pace, and there is an 'elder' man, got to be in his late 70's walking ahead of me... with a limp using a walking stick.  Now then, I say to myself as I'm walking along, come on then lets chat him up, well I'm now getting out of puff and he seems to be just 'dawdling along' - I'm now hot and thinking I need to stop - I keep going and then my 15 minute alarm goes off (I have two thoughts, wow I've got this far in 15 minutes and I'm also realising just how out of condition I am (I am overweight - never wanted to be - it 'just happened' :))  I resent my alarm for a further 15 minutes, then carry on walking, I get to the end of the road, the gentleman crosses over the road and I turn left and enter onto the field which is on my way back home. I see this healthy looking young girl and I could just tell then when she gets onto the cycle/walking path she is going to start jogging - and she did.  I carried on walking and I began to notice that I was feeling 'better/fresher/awake than when I was in the house.  Next thing, I am heading off the field, the young girl is on her way back and I am now nearly home.  I get into my house and then..... off goes my 15 minute phone alarm. I have walked for 'Half an Hour' and I'm now back home, feeling secretly pleased with myself :)) I hope I can just keep getting 'out' there - I know it won't always be half an hour, even if I can do 10 minutes - I will be pleased.... my body deserves at least 10 minutes and I am the only one that can give it this - and in return, I am sure my body will be grateful Nighty Night xxx

Posts.Content: Now here's a thought for this thread.... should I be updating my post that I posted 'before' I went out or should we do new ones.  For now I am doing a new one..... You'll never believe me when I tell you this, its so true though and I have to copy and paste this to the Fatigue thread. So, I finally dragged myself off the settee, got changed and set off - outside the house I set my phone alarm for 10 minutes!!! - I thought I'd do 10 minutes 'there' and 10 minutes 'back' = 20 minutes (which would be 5 minutes longer than Monday). Off I go, brrrr it is chilly, lets walk a little faster, lets slow down - hmm, I seem to be further than Monday, lets walk a little more - (brain fog now, what time would my alarm be going off - have I missed it in my pocket).  Okay, lets turn round, walking away .... "ding-a-ling, ding-a-ling - okay its not the sound of my alarm but my alarm is going off.  Right, I'm setting it again for another 10 minutes and lets see where I'll be when it goes off.  Walking, walking, through the back gate, into the house, changing out of trousers that I have dedicated to walking (they are grey, I only ever where black - so most won't recognise me from afar) - folding said trousers, ding-a-ling, ding-a-ling - its the alarm. Now what I do have to say is, I truthfully, can't believe how much I did in '20 minutes!!!!!! 20 minutes!!! my perception of time whilst I'm in the house is so different.  Now then, since coming back in the house I have washed up (some from last night - no energy or inclination). wrote on a few threads (this is time consuming for me, due to bad spelling and slow computer).  Made a cup of tea and just about to feed the cats.  This is why I need to post on the Fatigue thread - it has given me 'some energy - not sure how much or for how long - but I do feel a little brighter for the fresh air and movement :))  Sorry to waffle - this should be my name Waffle haha xxx  Right so a good few hours later I have finally got online and a line haha and eventually got my photo to insert. Energy is still better than it normally would be - I'm just sitting with mrsox watching Eastenders :o (joke) xxxx

Posts.Content: Hello everyone, waffling coming along, you might want to get a cuppa first haha Hello Leolady56 - Wow hope you're having a great time in France, the photos are lovely, its amazing, we've recently found out we have relatives in France...  :o  apparently from when my late Grandfather was 'fighting' in the Second World War (I'll tell this story another time if anyone is interested).  Thank you for your kind and inspirational words, wait till I tell you about my walk the other day (I'll add it tomorrow as this post is another chapter towards War and Peace). You know when I first mentioned on the "Fatigued Thread" about us starting a "Walking Thread", I had thought, well there are 'walking groups' to inspire people - I wonder if a Walking Thread would work for us, I certainly would like and am in need of encouragement. When I was writing about it I was thinking to myself 'everyone is going to think I'm you mad' (okay confirm that I'm mad).  How wrong was I - I can't believe how many ladies have said how it is inspiring them. Then with the fantastic names that you and PennyL came up with, it just had to be.  This just goes to 'show/prove' - 'we are normal with the thoughts' what we go through, the various feelings we have, what we feel etc.   Whats even nicer, is our truthfulness, the shear honesty of how we feel, how are day is and the inspiration this thread is giving all of us.   Owww Happybird - Your post was lovely and your photograph for me 'honestly made me cry - don't panic, happy tears, my eyes are filling again typing this.  Firstly, how very, very kind and thoughtful to dedicate such a beautiful photograph to me.  If you don't mind, please can I copy it and use it as my screen background on my computer - it is such an inspirational photograph 'Thank You' again. I didn't know about the Polar Bear on the Isle of Wight - I can see him and how amazing he looks too. As a child we would go on holiday to the Isle of Wight, Bournemouth and in later years Eastbourne - a few memories from Bournemouth was a very long sloping road down to the beach and the other was a 'life' on the front of a cliff (I would of said mountain as a child haha).  Then Eastbourne we would go on the pier and watch a man making seagulls and other animals out of glass, we used to watch him actually glass blowing, then there was the bandstand and near there was a lady that 'lived' on the beach, the story we were told, was her husband was killed at sea (may of been during the war) she wouldn't accept this and was waiting for him to return (I was only about 8 or 9 at the time so didn't really understand how sad this was at the time).  Thank you for such a kind a lovely gesture - this photo shows us all what we have to look forward to, what is out there and it's free - with the feeling of the wind :) the smell of the sea or countryside and the wonderful views - they are there for us, like you say, if we just open up our minds to it - its a goal for us to work towards. Hello PennyL - your photo is lovely, I wonder what the story is to this house? Does the sea ever surround it - wow, imagine living there.  The sound of the sea would be something else and imagine the sea spray on a really stormy and windy night wowwww.   Well Done to you and your hubby for having your first walk on the beach - I don't know between you and Happybird your both making me quiet envious - Birmingham just hasn't got the same scenery (you'll see this with a photo that I'll post in a day or two - I'm getting a complex with how long this post is :o  ronstar - so love the photographs and they inspiration you are giving us.  I've wrote down your stats (hey I'm sound more fit already, with the stats hehehe).  I don't think I'll be doing the run 5 mins for some time, however, it has given us guidance of things we can do and tweak to build up stamina etc.  Mine will more than likely start with Walk - maybe a little faster walk for 30 secs (that is a lot when your walking, it is) then back to normal, then faster again etc - I know they walking fast is very good for you - like you say, one step at a time - doing what we feel comfortable with. Hi Violetsniff - Massive "Well Done" on the 9 months!!!!! wow, I do hope with everyones inspiration we can all keep going.  I'll be the first to admit how out of breath, shape and condition I am in - this as got to change (owww I think I've heard myself say this before many times over the years).  Cannon, you say you don't get breathless now - have you noticed any other changes within yourself? Now then a little confession, (not sure if I've mentioned this three or four times before haha) I came down with the 'lurgy - flu' on the 1st January ~ New Years Day..... I have only once felt as poorly, this about 2 years back, on Christmas Day that time, that only knocked me about for a few weeks though. After that I have been a little OCD with hand sanitiser, swopping queues (didn't realise it was spelt like this)  in the shop because (wait for this)... I can tell if the assistant has a cold just by looking at their nose!!! :o (My Mom goes mad, when I said lets move the person has a cold and Mom been Mom then goes up to the said person and asks... 9 times out of 10 I'm right hahaha).  So, with my hand sanitiser and my new skill of 'nose reading' ;) I had 'not had a cold or sniffle for just over ONE YEAR!! then I came down with this.  Well here comes my confession, up until this Walking Thread (well it is in the Fatigue Thread - I'll have to copy my post and picture onto here), up until then, I had not been 'outside' my house (I have nipped in and out the back garden), I mean actually 'outside' the boundary of our house since New Years Day - mainly do to feeling really poorly, as I have felt better I still don't want to drive yet (its coming back slowly). I've done shopping online and anything else I've got my other half to do.   Now you can see how the walking thread became an idea - I wanted to get out, just no motivation, stamina or interest..... Until you lovely ladies all started posting and it honestly pushed me - okay, so my first walk was 10 minutes there and 10 minutes back - but I DID IT - the first time since 'New Year' ..... Thank You Ladies, Thank You LeoLady58 putting the Walking Thread together - Honeslty YOU ARE ALL AMAZING - and I really do need to post on the Fatigue Thread to let everyone know the benefits I felt since my first walk on Monday. I am going, but feel I need to add, it is a massive effort to go out at the moment, when I have got out, after about 10 minutes I can feel my brain start to 'open up' and feel fresher - I can feel it when I get back in the house, as LeoLady58 said, I can feel 'the inner me waking up 'a little' and this is one I am trying to take in and remember 'out of 24 hours in the day - surely I can give my brain and my body 20 minutes - I keep saying its not for me - its for my brain and my body its gone though a lot so I am helping it :) I'm stopping ladies, WAKE UP - mind you with the time..... GO TO SLEEP ~  THANK YOU ALL SO MUCH xxxxxx

Posts.Content: Hello,  I want to share this with you all. You may or may not know, when I had my lumpectomy operation, I had the combined Radiotherapy treatment at the same time.  It is called "TARGIT IROT" (Intra-operative RadioTherapy).  By having this type of operation and combined radiotherapy treatment, that was it, my treatment was over, all done,  all within the one operation (in addition I do have daily Letrozole tablets). This type of treatment is suitable for, I believe, a single lump - lumpectomy, requiring radiotherapy treatment. If everything worked out, I was able to do away with having daily radiotherapy treatment over the course of 3 to 4 weeks! I was blessed, my treatment was done.  I did not have to have daily radiotherapy, the possible side effects of burning to my skin, I didn't have the travel daily, I didn't have the extra stress and worry, I've come back to add this, with this type of treatment you 'can' if needed later on in life still have additional radiotherapy to the same bust too, whereas with the 'daily' radiotherapy you can't have anymore. There are so many benefits.  For the patient the list of benefits go on and on and we as patients are what matters - it's our lives, our time and I suppose its our money that has gone into the NHS, so we should be the ones to benefit from a treatment that 'is' available. This treatment will save the NHS money, time and free up radiotherapy staff and machines for other patients needing radiotherapy treatment, and here is where this wonderful treatment instead of being welcomed, the problems start, and I believe, all from within the NHS -  the Radiotherapy departments saying it will take away their jobs, instead of looking further ahead, that it will free up their skills and machines for other patients that require various different types of radiotherapy. They bring the cost of the machine into question, this machine will save so much time for both the NHS and the patient, save on electric used, save on carbon footprint again, it will save on more than it will cost in the long run, because of this, instead of NICE approving it in full, NICE have given 'Limited Approval' - they are putting hurdles in place for the patient to have to jump over, at a time when we are vulnerable and in an environment that we know nothing about! The sad thing, I believe even now, ladies being diagnosed that would be suitable for this type of treatment, even this week are not told of this is treatment or that the treatment is available, let alone offered it. I find it sad that NICE have limited is approval, one example.....'only using machines that are already available' - these machines are in 'some' NHS Hospitals - so where is the fairness in this, this should be available to all.....  This leads me to wonder, I know at a time like this the patient shouldn't have to be chasing around asking questions, however, this is how it is.  I was thinking could we get a list of all the NHS Hospitals that have these machines and then list them on here.  (i.e. I am 99% certain Royal Free in London has this machine).  Then under the NHS 'Choose and Book' scheme patients at least stand a chance at having this type of treatment. The Recommendations are:-  1.1 The Intrabeam radiotherapy system is not recommended for routine commissioning for adjuvant treatment of early invasive breast cancer during breast-conserving surgical removal of the tumour.  1.2 Use of the Intrabeam radiotherapy system is recommended only using machines that are already available and in conjunction with NHS England specified clinical governance, data collection and submission arrangements.  1.3 The procedure should only be carried out by clinicians with specific training in the use of the Intrabeam radiotherapy system. 1.4 Patient selection for Intrabeam radiotherapy should be done by a multidisciplinary team experienced in the management of early invasive breast cancer, which includes both breast surgeons and clinical oncologists. 1.5 Clinicians wishing to undertake Intrabeam radiotherapy should take the following actions: Inform the clinical governance leads in their NHS trusts. Ensure that patients understand the uncertainties about the procedure and inform them about alternative treatment options. Provide patients with NICE's written information on the evidence of the risks and benefits of the range of treatment options available as an aid to shared decision-making. So basically, this wonderful treatment that is available for us, that keeps getting pushed back, has finally being given 'Limited approval' - just to make it that little bit harder for us as patients to receive, at a time when we are already feeling vulnerable. I am passion about getting the word out on this treatment, giving ladies the knowledge that this treatment is out there, that it is available on the NHS - you just have to 'ask' and maybe 'ask again' and then ask where you can have this. I have waited months to see if 'one person on this website' would be writing saying how they have been offered this amazing treatment, unless I've missed it, I don't think anyone has - hence why I've waffled on in this post. If this post helps just one person receive this treatment, I am happy.  With Love to you all xxxx Link to NICE website and page (I hope)....  www.nice.org.uk/.../1-RecommendationsWell, at the time of my operation NICE was reviewing this treatment, finally, in January of this year, NICE has recommended this treatment, sadly with certain 'provisos' Link to University College London website and page (I hope) relating to limited approval: www.ucl.ac.uk/.../nhs-breast-cancer-patients-benefit-from-ucl-pioneered-treatment
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy with combined Radiotherapy given "Limited Approval" TARGIT...

Posts.Content: Hi ArgyMargy, I understand these machines are already in various hospitals around the country - so I truly believe the patient should be told about this type of treatment and where it is available.  Even on the bases of 'so patients know about it' and can make up their own minds. The uncertainties with regard to the radiotherapy part of the treatment, I believe could be described as similar to when having a lumpectomy and surgeon getting 'clear' margins.  Thankfully for most all is fine and only one lot of treatment is required (as was in my case). I just think patients should be given the choice.  At the very least at least the question can be asked if a patient is suitable for this type of treatment.  I understand the NHS can't just magic up money to place these machines in every hospital, however, these machines and technology are already sitting in 'some' hospitals in the UK - I just would like Breast Cancer Patients that are suitable to be given the chance to have this type of treatment. I think it is good that we are able to talk about it and raise awareness. Sorry I've waffled on xx This treatment was given 'limited approval' 6 months ago, I wonder how many ladies on here have been either told or offered this type of treatment.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy with combined Radiotherapy given "Limited Approval" TARGIT...

Posts.Content: Hello Anonymous49, Sadly, I had my operation 'before' this 'limited approval' - I had to pay for my treatment, saving the NHS a little I suppose. I mean, look at the travelling this operation could of saved you (if you were suitable for the combined), along with so many others.   What makes this worse, I believe Swindon is one of the Hospitals 'with' this machine,  this is why we need to get the word out there. I will at some point try to find out which hospitals have this machine. Currently, I believe the Hospitals with this machine, are:- Royal Free, The Whittington, Guy's in London, Winchester, Swindon and Harlow. xxxx
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy with combined Radiotherapy given "Limited Approval" TARGIT...

Posts.Content: Hello Anonymouse49,  Thank you for asking, the more that we ask the more the word will be heard.  Well thats a tricky one, being too young versa the treatment, well then, I think age is great to have on your side and it answer the question for both of us. It is interesting about them not currently offering treatment to women over 50 for a number of reasons. This treatment had 'limited approval' back in January of this year, so that's some 6 months and still not being offered. and what is even worse, Swindon was one of the Hospitals I believe trialing this treatment -  They have the machine there with staff qualified to use it!!!   I really don't think this is fair. My hope, any lady that finds herself unfortunately enough to be here, needing treatment for Lumpectomy along with Radiotherapy and is over 50 - will now have this information and can ask if you are suitable for this treatment. If you are under or near to these hospitals:- Royal Free, The Whittington, Guy's in London, Winchester, Swindon and Harlow. Ask if you are suitable for Targit IORT - Plus, the NHS have the 'Choose and Book' service, this allows you to have the option to 'Choose' the Hospital where you would like your treatment. Thank you again Anonymouse49 - we are both wiser from you phone call.

Posts.Content: You are all doing amazing, I have to say no walk for me today, my day didn't to go to plan - I hadn't planned it, it just changed from the start. Along sad story cut short...I had heard via Neighbourhood Watch group on Facebook about a poorly fox on the other side of the field to where I live, I contacted the fox rescue that I have had help from a few years back, I was told they had received any update, the person had called back to say the fox had now ran off into the bushes.  I said to the fox rescue, I've got a feeling about this, my gut instinct is telling me to go and check, I said I would and I'd phone back with an update. So, planning ahead, I take some cat food, cat carrier and drive around the roads to get to the other side of field (first time driving since September - needs must, I could of walked, but if fox is there I'd never of been able to carry all the way back, so I drive).  I get to area and look about I can't see anything - but this is a field with bushes all around.  I look at the photo on Facebook and walk and look and finally I think I'm in right area (I take a photo - I'm exactly there, this was spooky, in the exact place).  I look around, nothing, being honest, I am relieved, how would I catch him, how would I carry him, what will I do, these are all questions now going through me mind.  Then..... I spot a little ball of rusty brown fur!!!! owwwww I've now got all these questions again.  I phone a person I know that has helped with fox rescued a lot but due to health reasons can't drive, they say if I can catch Foxy :o it bring him/her over.  At this, an RSPCA man arrives, he is walking over to me, he is a really nice man and fairly new to the job (I 'had' lost faith in the RSPCA over the year and to be honest this guy did help win me back over - a little).  We both agree fox is in a bad way more than likely hit by a vehicle.  I ask if he catches fox I will take it to rescuer, then to vets for assessment, fluids and treatment - then on to rescue in Northampton for hopeful recovery and return back here when well enough. Fox puts up 'no' struggle going into cat carrier. I phone OH and asked if he'd drive me and foxy to other side of town. (this was my Valentine's present :)) which I am more than happy with). I said I'd keep this short and I'm not.  Got to Vets, gave all details, OH handed cat carrier over to the nurse to take in to room to see the vet, as he did this the fox made this little cry.  Nurse took into vet and came 'straight' out and said I'm sorry I think it has 'just' passed away.  We went and the poor little girl had gone. Her gums were so pale, the vet thinks she was hit by a vehicle and could either have internal injuries, broken leg, or hip, or back any of this plus all the time after this lying around in the cold. Owww my brain wasn't thinking right when all this happened and I'm mad and upset with myself of not taking her to a nearer vet, for not wrapping her up to get her warm - I just didn't think, why I don't know, these are the things that normally come naturally to me, its like I've forgotten what to do and I'm learning all over again - I put a blanket on the floor of the carrier, I should of put extra bedding in with her, should I of let her go with the RSPCA man - so many questions. Its rubbish, you try to help and end up feeling to blame.  So, my friends, this is why I didn't get out and do my walk today. You are all putting me to shame, keep it up, you are all amazing - I will try with every intention tomorrow to get out and walk - sorry to of waffled on.  Nighty Night xxx    Ps.  Happybird I'm on letrozole, minimum side effects - I'll post tomorrow about it zzzzzZZZzzzzz

Posts.Content: I must just add, these are my own opinions, I believe for both our health and mental state we need to have treatments as soon as possible.   If the NHS were offering this treatment as they should be then fantastic, this treatment was given limited approval by NICE over a year ago and I am still to hear of anyone being offer this on the NHS. If I had Private Health Insurance I would not be staying on a 'waiting list', never knowing 'if' it will happen.  I know in my heart, this treatment is being delayed, withheld, whatever you want to call it due to people 'thinking' (I believe wrongly) they will be out of jobs in the long term, that the radiotherapy part of this treatment is taking so called 'work' away from the Radiotherapy units - in my opinion, it wouldn't do this, it would free up machines to allow for others with different needs for receive treatments sooner.   This treatment is available through a limited number of Hospitals on the NHS - we need to shout out for this treatment to be given, for any ladies coming along - they need to be told about this treatment (I believe a Doctor by law is supposed to tell their patent of 'all' potential treatments available), they need to be offered and given this treatment.   We are in such a vulnerable state when we are first diagnosed we don't want to have to trawl around looking for treatments to have - this should be offered, it is our right.   Betty, I feel confident you should be able to get this operation via. the NHS if you are prepared to travel, if not, then there is something drastically wrong and it needs bring out for all to hear. If you want to chat at all, please feel free to message me  xxxx
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy with combined Radiotherapy given "Limited Approval" TARGIT...

Posts.Content: Dear Georgia78  This is my concern, we are even made aware of this treatment, let alone getting offered it.  My treatment as such is finished, I could walk away, I can't, I want every person that is suitable for this treatment to be told about it and offer it.  I can't put out of my mind the fear I felt at the beginning and how finding this amazing treatment along with this fantastic forum helped me... I'm a Fruit Loop haha    I thank God I was blessed to be able to have the TARGIT IORT treatment, two reasons alone are... 1). My darling mum is in her late 80's, mum is my life and I am hers.   I really did not want to tell mum of my diagnosis, this way, I was able to say I was having 'a lump removed', and this is just how it seemed.   2). My BC was on left side, this caused me a lot of worry and concern, this treatment took away a lot of my fears in this regards.   Many of you know, this can make radiotherapy treatment that bit more awkward.  A lot of ladies have had the 'deep breath hold' treatment. I am not medial - so please what I type are my own thoughts and opinions.... With regards to chemo, I can't answer this.  I would 'think' this treatment would still be approached in the same way.  Depending if chemo was suggested 'before' or 'after' operation - I would say with both options the chemo would be able to be started sooner, as straight away the time scale of 3 or 4 weeks radiotherapy has been cut to 'one day'.   This combined operation and radiotherapy is not suitable for everyone one, for example, if you have more than one lump then I believe this treatment isn't suitable.   This all said, I feel the NHS need to start pushing this treatment to all suitable patients, both Doctors and BC nurses should be making all patients aware.

Whilst out I did see a lady that I hadn't seen for a long time, it was sad, but, good to see she is still around.   I took a photo of one of the blue bells in the woods near to me today, it stood out from all the others... it looked 'a pinky/purple' rather than blue.  I will go back tomorrow and take another photograph with some of the others in the background, only having this one in the photo there is nothing to compare the colours to. This news of Notre Dame Cathedral is so heartbreakingly sad, 850 years old.  To see it get ravaged like this, it only makes me think of what humans are doing to our planet.  We are the ones that should know better, yet we are the ones that create so much damage (I know its not everyone - maybe I should delete these last few sentences, but, its how I feel.  We have so much good in the world, on our planet but we are destroying it.  I mean those nets across the cliffs to stop the birds from nesting - how crazy!!) I'm stopping this otherwise I'll be writing all night arrghh. Loving all the photos and posts.  Wishing you all well with appointments, treatments, results - sending love and hugs to you all xxxxx

Posts.Content: Hi Mirabo - I've tried to have a nosey at what you've been up to, sadly, the link doesn't work. Sorry to hear you've knocked yourself up so to speak, these lawnmowers can have a mind of there own, I really hope it's nothing to serious.  Will be thinking about with your upcoming mammogram and ultra sound not to forget the radiotherapy treatment.   If you post using the 'old editor' it tells you this on the page where you type your post.... it says You are using the old editor, this allows image uploads. if you look above the box where you type you will see.... B I then an x and another x, followed by dot and line, number and line, strange line, strange line in grey, a 'back arrow' and a grey forward arrow.  then a grey chain, then a grey 'broken chain' then....... dun, dun, dunnnnnnn what looks like a "TV" with a small circle with a + sign in it... click that one (the tv looking sign) this will then open a box saying 'insert/edit media' look 3 lines done, it says File with a blank space then the word 'browse' click browse.... this will then look through your photos (hope you're still with me) when you find your photo - double click the photo. this will then start to upload - it may take time, you will see a green bar in the blank space that was by the word 'browse' zzzZZzz this will automatically start to upload the photo and after a while the photo will appear in the box.... then click on 'insert' or you can click 'cancel' and start all over again. after you have clicked 'insert' - the photo will the appear in your typing box - either below or above you typing - when you're happy click the green button with the word 'Post and hey presto - fingers crossed and all that 'it might have worked' - if not, close windows, walk away from the computer, switch kettle on and go and have a cup of tea before screaming into a cushion xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hello ronstar, it is so good to hear from you.  You won't bring the vibe down. We are each who we are and how we feel is us - it is easier to come on here when we are in a 'good place' or feeling a upbeat - writing on here when we are down and things don't feel good is hard and takes courage. I do believe just writing it down and getting it out of our heads is a good thing, plus this is where the site the lovely ladies and gents come into their own, hearing different view points can 'sometimes' spark a thought that can change everything. I am sorry to read of your relatives passing, makes it all the sadder knowing they were young. It seems like you hear about it all the time, every time you talk to someone or listen to the radio or tv you hear it over and over again.  I would think your family will understand you not being at the funeral. I have a second-cousin, we are not close, messages via. Facebook,  29 and a single parent - she has been given 6 to 12 months!!! My goodness, how do they carry on when hearing this.  In truth, they have to, they have to do what is right for them - to live as best they can for as long as they can. (I don't mean any of this light hearted and I hope it is coming out how I mean it. You can tell me to mind my own business, just read what I say then ignore what I've said or stick your fingers up at me hahaha..... (oww and it may come across a little mixed up, its all meant in a good way).... You can't blame your treatment on your daughters actions. You may of helped open her eyes to the life is short - but, really, this is a good thing, I think this is one lesson we learn from this dreaded 'thing'.  Once we can get over the shock, it gives us a kick up the a** so to say, to know what we 'should' do - doing it, well thats another story.  If you were looking in on this situation, you might see it differently as being the Mom.... We all think we know what is best, what is right and no one will truly change our mind until we are either ready to change or we see it in a different way. (then its all the 'I told you so's).   Your daughter getting married, just the word marriage will of triggered so many emotions and thoughts to you, even how you thought it would be or not be.  One good thing, where its right or wrong - it is getting you to travel to see your daughter and to met boyfriend.  I am finding I want to write so much, I won't, you know how I waffle.  What I'm trying to say is... Okay your daughter is getting married to what we have in mind is a 'wrong-un' - this is your daughters choice and if she has it wrong, I pray she will see sense and they will go there separate ways.  Maybe he has been arrested no end of times, maybe though, he is the nicest person you will meet, maybe he worships your daughter and treats her like a Princess, maybe once married they will settle to be so happy, maybe if he's not what he should be your daughter will say that is was wrong or its not working and they will go there separate ways ....... what I'm saying is there are so many 'maybes' that once your out there you may see it for how it truly is - don't let it push you and your daughter apart, just go with it - go with the live for today. Indirectly your daughters actions are already reaping rewards..... her Mom is coming to America to see her, Florida at that.  I believe you will know and fell far better going there and seeing for yourself. I hope this comes across how I've mean it. Sending you a massive big squiggy hug and loads of love xxxxx Ps.  I've not got out and walked for weeks, I've lost my motivation for getting out there, need to give myself a kick up the .... xxx

Please don't let the actions of others, where friends or family 'bring you down' - you ignore their reactions and as someone said to me years back 'it is your choice on how you react' - not your friends.  Meaning, if someone says something and it upsets you, you possibly would say, "you really upset me with what you said" and in truth..... I was with this thread at the start, just after my operation, then due to what ever reasons, pressures of life, returning to work, being over weight, not fit, fat, etc, etc. all excuses that really aren't acceptable - I 'stopped' walking.  Well 12 months on and I have had a private blood test with lots of tests 'out of range' all in the 'high' region..... hence here I am back again, I have walked for the last week or so, using an app called 'Walking' - this gives the information however it is for a 'set time' - so if I am walking a little longer it is not getting logged. Any thoughts would be appreciated - Keep Walking  xx

Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Dearest Happybird, I was so happy to see you had come back and then I read your post.  This is so, so very sad, why is life so cruel.  Like you say you have gone thought this so you can relate to some of the feelings your partner is going though.  I hope I don't speak out of turn when I say this, I mean it sincerely.... The liver is an amazing organ, it is the only internal organ that can re-grow, there are so many treatments available, I hope and pray something may be suitable for your partner.  (the hot knife, ablation).  My late father was referred to the Royal Free Hospital in London (there are other hospitals now with classed as 'Centre of Excellance', once there my Dad was diagnosed with a rare form of cancer called 'neuroendocrine' in his stomach, what we didn't know, it had also spread to his liver. My late father was living life fairly normal with, walking around, gardening etc with... 90% of his liver full of tumours! Dads body was surviving and working with 10%!! - the specialist in London was looking at a monthly infection to 'keep everything' at bay and then if there was any shrinkage further treatment would be looked into .... What I am trying to say, and I sincerely mean this with all my heart, I pray that your partner has hope of responding to a treatment. I, like others on here understand about stopping the tamoxifen - it would be good for you to reconsider, take it one day at a time - you can always stop another time, for now, your partner and family and friends need you to be looking after yourself - so you can get thought this together. If you decide not to take it, then know we will still support you - we just want you to give it a re-think, but will totally respect your decision. My heart breaks for you, it truly does.  Always here for you, like it or not - I've got shoulders you can lean on, ears that I can listen and a mouth in case you need a few words of comfort or shouting at, most of all I have arms that can hug you. Your name always stood out to me and I have thought of you often.  I still have the photo you took as my wallpaper on my computer. You told me about the Polar Bear.....   Thinking of you and your partner, sending love and strength xxxx

Posts.Content: Well I made the effort to get out today, walked just over a mile again, first half 'up hill' - oww what a struggle, I shall keep persevering (and I didn't have my fingers crossed when I typed this).  Not sure how others are getting on, time just seems to run away from me, from when I get up, make something to eat (having to try hard now, as need to get blood sugar numbers down, so trying to cut out/down on carbohydrates).  After eating go for walk, get home and before I know it the day has gone.... I am so behind, one Christmas present got, no Christmas cards wrote, behind with work and house is a tip.... Helpppppppp Saying this, I am not stopping my walks, this is actually 'for me' - so I will carry on, slowly, slowly.  Last year when we started this thread I stopped walking after a week or so, and can only wonder where I would be health and fitness wise now 'if' id kept it up.  Well this time I intend to keep the walking up (holding breath and trying to believe myself).  I need to my blood sugars on an Hb1AC test (how blood looks over 3 months test) the range given is 20 - 42 mol/mol mine is/was 68, so well over.  (plus other readings out of range including Liver; Gamma GT and ALT).  So, before I go to doctors I am trying to change diet and get some exercise and see if I can help get the numbers down owwww - one thing after another. Leolady56 if you could see how I look going for my walks, I laugh at myself, purpose looking like a 'bag lady' so I'm left alone hahaha, you are right it is the mind imagining all types of things happening. I think the more I am going out the more I am feeling a little more settled whilst out - however, if I do have 'wobble' days, I will check in and out on here, 'Thank you for this'.  I really hope you are feeling better, it's not nice when we have a Loop down, just like a Chain we are only as strong as our links - Sending love and Big Hugs xxx Flossie25 sounds like you have had a good and productive day, why does it always seem to me that everyone can get lots done and here I am hours later still in the same place arrgghhh.   I suppose the walk is the only activity that I can see that I have done 'something' yet still seem to fall back behind as soon as I walk back through the door arrgghh xxxxx Picture from my walk today: Starlings happily singing in a tree... Sending love to all - Nighty Night xxxx

Posts.Content: It’s so sad, so many ducks and swans have ‘starved’ to death through the silly councils telling people not to feed bread.  Swans and Ducks, etc can eat bread - if that’s all people have then feed this too them. A dear lady runs a wildlife rescue, “Linjoy” - she rescues ‘any living animal or creature in need of help’. All with the aim of releasing back to the wild - they have had so many cases of swans on the brink of death due to starvation due to people believing that they shouldn’t eat bread. Please feed bread to the waterfowl - it might not have much nutritional value (my thoughts) - but it certainly does feed them.   It goes without saying, but I will (haha) - please don’t feed mouldy bread as this cause serious health issues with the mould spores etc.  Sending love to all xxxx

Posts.Content: Hello ladies and gents, I’m still doing my walking, the last two days have been tough - just didn’t want to go, but... I did and then had my best overall number of steps ever, well since keeping count.  I did (drum roll, if I do say so myself) I did 11,000+ steps. Mind you I looked like a beetroot when I crawled home haha   Sunnyone - could I ask a big favour of you and of course any of the ladies and gents on here.... There is a social media group on a well known website beginning with F - the Council is wanting to flatten the a 100+ Years old Allotments site and home to Robert the Allotment cat, Robert was feral and has other friends living at the Allotments with him.  The Plot Holders are trying to raise awareness and get signatures on a petition, so far so many kind people have signed that they are over 7,000 - they need more signatures to get Birmingham City Council to listen.  The reason for this, Perry Barr, Birmingham will be hosting the Commonwealth Games for 2 weeks in 2022. They support the Commonwealth Games, however the Allotments grounds were never part of  this progect. Now BCCouncil want to flatten the Allotments and lay to concrete to create a ‘queuing system’ for transport!! Please, would you help spread the word, sign and share the petition, you can even follow Robert the Allotment Cat on Twitter   The Group is called ‘Save Walsall Road Allotments’ - if any of you would sign and share this round be amazing - Thank You xxxx I’m not sure if I could put a link up to petition at the change.org website   sending love to all

AnnJac I have to laugh, I found out how to do this on Friday, I did the most steps that I had, and had three green rings.... apart from the calories, well, I found I could alter this, so now steps are at 3,500 and Calories Burned are now at 1,500 = 4 green rings, okay I cheated, but, it made me feel good hahaha I must say, I was interested to learn what a 'swale' is - very interesting. Flossie25, I would so love to do early morning walks, I just don't think I will ever get there.  With been awake half the night by morning I am fast asleep and not surfacing till around mid-day and by the time I have procrastinated its getting on for 2:30pm before I get out walking! Owwww I'd love to turn this around. Violetsniff, your walking results are great, plus remember these only add on whilst caring your phone, mine look quite sad as I'm trying not to look at phone so often, so not caring about. Sunnyone, Thank you so much, the more people that can sign and share the petetion the better.  I haven't got an Allotment, I would love one, like you say, this would be tragic for them, even life changing.  Whats more maddening, the Commonwealth Games committee have said 'they do not need this land'.  It is the Council trying to steal it whilst using the Commonwealth Games as a cover - shameful. HappyFeet1, I love your photos, I love everyone, I have to say the Donkey and the Longhorn (?) cow are beautiful.    seaspirit44, I hope you are keeping well, loving the photographs - your daughter looks a good skier.  I've never been sking on snow, many years ago we tried learning at a local 'dry slope' - quiet entertaining hahaha. yellowroses, Thank you for your kind words, it is so true, they should leave this land alone.  I haven't got an Allotment, I'm trying to support for a couple of reasons, mainly this land as been an Allotment left to the people from the Calthorpe Estate, a wealthy family many years back, left for the people to use - so how are the Council to even begin to do this.  Then it goes deeper, the land has been Allotments through '2 World Wars' - it is fully used and well looked after, the Plot Holders are from all different countries, they have rescued chickens living there and also have 'Robert the Allotment Cat' and his friends, once feral and now all loved, fed and looked after. I believe the petition has gathered over 8,800 signatures - I really hope it snowballs and they get so many more. Amalie, well done you with your bike.  Maybe as my strength builds up I can progress onto my bike. I have spoiled myself, I brought a second hand battery powered bike and I love it (haven't used it this year) - well I think it was a bad move, I love it, I love going out on it - the trouble is, I can never see me going back to a peddle bike, I don't think I would have the stamina, I really don't.  One to work on I suppose. Leolady56, I send both you and Mr. Leo my love and thoughts.  This BC certainly sets off so many rollercoaster rides with our thoughts.  I had a hard time dealing with my first year mammogram - a time when you think your putting it all behind you was like it was all out there in front of me, every emotion going and to be told 'come on you need to get a grip (yes around your neck if you say this once more haha).  I spoke with Mrsox a few weeks back about this very thing, she told me she was discharged and I was, oww thats good and then thought about it and said, I don't think they should actually say you are discharged, as it sounds like thats it 'off you go' - I think 12 months on and we are still in a vulnerable place and need to know we have support waiting in the background 'if' needed! Hearing your discharged to me makes me think of the army and war times when - thats it off you go.  I imagine they like to use that word to clear themselves of patients, if anything else or any concerns pop up we go to our local doctor.  I think it should be a, well all your treatment is finished with, if you need us we are always here for you, however, its always good to contact your doctor first, however, don't panic - we are here for you. Sending you great big hugs and very best wishes to Mr. Leo Ladies, if I have missed any of your out, please know its not intentional, these posts take me forever at the best of times. Sending you all great big hugs and loads of love and ..... keep walking, riding, biking, and anything else, just keep moving - even if its only getting up and walking around the living room a few times or into the garden and back, its a start and thats all that matters. Ps. Look how far I have come, I remember posting on here about been scared going out walking, and lovely Leolady said I could come on here and clock off and back in.  Slowly we can do this, little by little xxxxxxx

Posts.Content: Ladies, I went, get this, this is from someone that is sadly overweight and out of condition (and never thought I'd be either :(  Well ladies, I did it, I went out - what amazes me, when I stepped out the front door, I set alarm on phone for '10 minutes'...10 minutes!!!!! its nothing in the bigger picture of how I spend my day. I'm walking, brrrr its chilly, walking, owww I'm out of breath, come on keep walking, okay this going okay, cheeks and mouth tucked into my scarf, Walking hmmm, I've got a fair way, again thinking have I missed my '10 minute alarm' - not sure how to check (note to self: remember the time when you set alarm). Hmmmm, I think I'm going to turn round (remember I don't want to be out when other half gets back, as this walking is our secret).  Turns around, then a little while after 'alarm goes off'. Wow I think, my goodness, look how far you can get in '10 minutes!!!!!' I then set phone alarm for another 10 minutes and continue walking back home.... I'm back in the house with kettle on and alarm goes off!.  A 20 minute walk - just can't believe how far 10 minutes took me. Now ladies, Aspen castor oil, do you rub this on your eyebrows, etc or to you swallow it?? This could be added to the 'tips' tread too. I'm like you, I've not told many people, let me think, 5 in total or there about. Other half, brother (and his wife), sister, my Mom (Mom only knows I had a "lump" that would be better to remove than left :/   and two friends.... one a life long friend, which to be honest seems I don't have the friendship I thought - sad really. But 'hey hoe' I've got my new friends on here. You will get through this, each day is a step forward.  I think you will find all this will make you a stronger person - not standing for crap people give out and move so the best bit of all, we learn how to appreciate and live life. Pssssss Penny Lane, just wondering if your forgotten it now.... A whole new worlllllldddddd, a whole new worllllddddd :) couldn't resist haha.  LeoLady56 beat me to the secret code that once told you have to raise one leg and swear you will only share on Mondays to people eating Hot Cross Buns !  Loving the photos - the views are fantastic. LeoLady56 how brilliant typing in word and copying over.  I can't tell you how many posts I've written, waffling on and on (no!! stop that now) only to post it and they have disappeared - I've then given up :(    I'm wondering if this is worthy of a list on the 'Tips thread?" The photo of the tree with all its little burbles looks like its all dressed up for Christmas, how beautiful, unusual but beautiful.  Cannon well this will give me inspiration to keep walking, mind you my waist if it would like to ever make a reappearance, I recon I'll be walking for years - Very Well Done xxx  War and Peace is starting off again, sorry about this..... Owwww HappyBird this wind plays havoc with your cheeks :)) so funny.  So loving the photos and the Bumble Bee well who would think they are out already.  See with these walks and the sharing we are all starting to slowly wake up to our coming new lives, the nights are getting lighter and our journeys are moving forward - we are stronger, we are invincible, we are women (for Penny Lane and LeoLady56 to sing to us all :) I'm stopping waffling now - love to all you beautiful Ladies, hoping you all know how special you all are xxx Now if I'm not about - I'm asleep in a corner somewhere xxxxx

Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hello ladies, well, I have finally got myself out walking again, I went yesterday and again today..... after naughty missing at least two weeks!! Very bad!! I have to laugh though, it seems I have been meant to do these two walks, both were at times I would not walk and I'd pushed my self to go... Yesterday on the way back from my walk, going a different route, I walk into a young lad lying on the pavement, he had been knocked off his push bike on his way home from school.  Thankfully he was okay, very badly shaken up - the driver did not seem bothered, but, this could be shock.  Ambulance came and off I went. Then tonight, I don't walk normally of an evening, but was feeling 'come on you have to get out, try and achieve something today'. So, off I went, met a nice old chap that wanted to talk, so I walked and talked with him, again going a different direction to the way I wanted, but I felt this man wanted to talk, got to his house said goodbye and off I carried..... only to find a 'greyhound' dog walking in the road and a car narrowly missing him! I see the dog go down the path of a house and thought he was home - I looking like a nutter attract the lady in the window of the house (how is now looking at me like 'what do you want' - she comes out, I ask if she has a dog, at this the dog appears the lady screams and shuts the door.... I guessed the answer was 'no, she didn't have a dog' - her scream set me on to a 'oww what if he bites me, oww what do I do' I know, I'll take a photo and put on Facebook, then I notice the dog has a blue collar on him and a tag, I need to look at this haha, then I recall me other half saying a long time back 'how placid greyhounds are' so I call the dog - he ignores me, so, I go up and manage to look at the collar, the owner has a tag on it saying 'if found please scan me, I am microchipped', I know realise this dog shouldn't be out. I turn the tag over and I know the owners name and where he lives, so me and my new mate walk off together (me gently holding the collar) to where the gentleman that I know lives. (sorry I'm waffling). I gets to his house and the garage door is open, hmm I think that's it, that dog must of just walked out. Then I notice there is a window missing in the garage and no one is answering the door..... my mind is now on overdrive, I am thinking, someone has broken in, seen the dog and ran off..... then I have owww the owner may of fallen and the dog has got out - owww heavens for betsy his wife comes to the door totally oblivious to all of this. She looks at me and then looks at her dog, I explain all and let the dog go inside - she then tells me her husband has dementia and is always leaving doors open (I haven't seen her husband for around 7 or 8 years maybe longer, so this was sad to hear).  I am just about to go and turn around and the dog is back in the garage just about to let himself out again aaagghh! Thankfully the wife shuts the garage door and I hope all is good. Off I go walking home! I'm dreading to think what will happen tomorrow if I go out - maybe I should be staying home!  Sending love to all xxxxx

Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Dearest OCRKate, Of course you have to do what is right for you.  I hope you don't mind me saying a few things that might help and if they don't then please don't get offended by me saying them, this is not my intention and in truth I know at this moment in time you really don't need this. Would it be possible to go from 'session' to 'session' with the chemo - as in, 'just get one more done' then step back and recharge. Can you find a way to separate these feelings, it is not the chemo giving you the flash backs, the flash backs are they due to what happened not because of the chemo - it is your mind trying justify a reason not to have the chemo.   The chemo is to 'help' you - it has nothing to do with what happened to you as a child.  Maybe these flash backs are 'coming out of you'.  Having this journey at the start seems to break us - then, little by little we rebuild and although weak at first - I reckon we come out stronger and this could be the case for you, our minds are evil places and always make us see things at 'the very worse' - then when we face up to it, its not been as bad as our mind as made us believe it to be. I would like to add, your family and friends will support your decision - in truth what else can they do.  I don't know how far you are along with your chemo - but for you, try and get through another session, you are worth this, this is the new you developing from this, please try and stick at it if you can - then you can move forward knowing you have given it your very best. One other thought, on the social media site FaceB... look up The Speakman's - they are a fantastic couple, message them and tell them of your thoughts and fears and I am sure they will reach out and help you.  OCRKate, I know this is hard for you and it is your choice - whatever you do, we are always here for you and if you want to message me, if you think I could help you at all - please message me. Sending you love and great big hugs, Gail xx

Posts.Content: Oww dear Leonaw123, I do feel for you. You will worry, its human nature - we get nothing back in return just upset.  This all seems so un-fair and so un-necessary. If I was you, with a deep breath I would phone up and ask if your results are back and if not, when will they be. This 'might' jog them along.   I went and had mammogram, ultra sound and biopsy all within an hour of each other - then got told 'there and then' what it was, but, could not give me finer details until results where back.  I had to go back on the Friday to be told in full. (This was NHS in Birmingham - they seem to have a really good system in place - I could not fault any of it, well apart from my result :( - this is when this site and the girls on here took over, the help, support, care and comfort was amazing, to be accepted and taken in and helped when at my most vulnerable, well there are no words that can explain how thankful I am and always will be. (more than family and friends). I don't think it is about how 'good or bad' your results are - I think its the silly system and for this reason I would phone and make enquires, say it is causing you upset and distress not knowing.  Even blame a family member for pushing you to call xxx  (and as the old saying goes..... the squeaky wheel gets the oil.... which I take to mean if you speak out and ask you will get help or answers). x

Posts.Content: Owww mrsox  I so feel for you, it's all the not knowing, the uncertainty of what we want and what they think they want and what they want us to think we want them to think we want.  I said it like this to make you laugh, I'm not making light of this. I am sincerely sorry you have to go through this. I've read on here they like you to be strong minded and not crying (can't think of the right words) - so they know you have considered all options and you know what you want. Could you say that you would be willing to have the bilateral on the 15th December - could they do it then (please). If not, why not? Is it an operation that you can have done at the same time, if so when? (or take a friend with you to ask or prompt the questions).  mrsox we are all here for you, if we can help to take or easy your worry then there is enough of us to get you through this.  Don't bottle it up, share it with us and between us all we can work it out (sounds like I'm singing a line from The Beatles).  We can, we all know when we have our rational heads on - worrying won't help us, it drains us, and ruins the fun of the present - the here and now.  I know its a worrying time - (don't want to sound hard and its meant in a good way) 'it is what it is' no amount of worrying will change this - put, that energy can be used to change the way you think - you have your army here (some could say the Barmy Army others the Bonkers Army) either way we are here for you.  You can do this - Sending Love and Hugs xxxxxx
Posts.Title: mrsox

Posts.Content: Hello Flopsyuk, I am new to all this, so in a way I can't offer experienced advice.  What I will say, I personally find, when it is to to with my own health I am hopeless at asking for or speaking up for myself.  If its for anyone else, I am straight in there. What you could do, I'm not sure if this is any help, I would say contact your Oncologist and say you have been talking this over with family, you have told them what the letter to your doctor said, and they like you, totally disagree with what has been wrote - it looks like she have misunderstood how you are coping, could she re-write to your doctor telling him/her that you 'more than struggle on a daily basis'.  If she is not willing to do this, then, I would look into changing (again, I'm not confident enough to say its my decision; I would say my family want me to do this). I feel so much for you, I am only starting out on this road, but, what I have seen with others, you need to find a way to speak up for yourself.  One friend said to a family member (about something completely different, but, it made sense).... remember you are living with this every day, your doctor only sees you for that short appointment time and then moves on to the next patient: How will they know you are not happy or something is not right - if you don't tell them. I hope this helps in some way xx
Posts.Title: Has anyone changed consultant (Oncologist) due to problems with them...

Posts.Content: Dear Garome63, Welcome to the mad house, I am sorry you have found yourself here, however, as mad as we all are between us all we are a great bunch.  Lets hope your stay here is brief, if it turns out not to be, then we have your back and will help you through this. When I first went to me doctors with a slight dimple, my doctor had no concerns and referred me under the '2 week referral scheme' (not sure of the correct name) basically, if BC is suspected your doctor refers you and you see specialist at BC Clinic in hospital 'within' two weeks.  Your '5 weeks' to me is not acceptable.  I think you need to go back to your doctor and ask to be referred under this system. The system works very well.  You see a breast surgeon, have a mammogram, followed by an ultra sound, if there is an area they are unsure about (for numerous reasons, scar tissue, cyst, BC, fatty lump, etc) they will do a biopsy (normally there and then) and from this can give you an 'idea' of how everything is looking. You are very right the delay and waiting will cause you anxiety - I reckon most if not all ladies on here will say 'it's the waiting for results or treatment plan' that causes the most upset and stress.  Once you know what you are dealing with - you have control and know whats going on. Not wanting to worry you, but, better said than you think it yourself.... "If" there is anything wrong, first remember you have only a few months ago had a clear mammogram, so you hopefully could be worrying over nothing.  If it is something, well, you have set the ball rolling and have done something about it rather than waiting.  There are so many treatments available and believe me 'you will get through it' - once you know what is happening we can take it from there. Lets really hope your stay here is short and there is nothing for you to worry about.   Please keep us updated and if you have any questions or concerns don't keep them to yourself, there is always a 'Fruit Loop' about willing to help.   If you feel lonely during the night time hours (most of us start here, with all the 'what if's, etc' - look for the thread called 'Awake' and feel free to join in, ask questions, share your worries etc and we will do our best to help you through this. Sending hugs xxxx
Posts.Title: Puckering on breast. Is this likely to be Breast cancer?

Posts.Content: Great question 232pookie - I'm 18 months on letrozole time is flying past, I can still remember the worry at taking the first tablet, yet what I did yesterday or the day before well, thats another story so to speak. I can relate to your post, I felt I was very fortunate with having 'very few, if any side effects'.... until, like Leolady56has suggested, until it started to build up, over the last few months I have developed 'trigger thumb' (same as trigger finger). It came on 'over night' I was asleep in bed and woke up with a pain in my thumb and could not bend it!! This carried on for some weeks, I was okay with this as it was in my right hand and I am left handed. Then same thing happened 'left thumb' locked - so for a few weeks I was 'hmmm what do to, read up on it and read that it can go without an operation, so first thought is to give it time. Sure enough, it has gone from my right thumb but, still remains in my left thumb.  Moving forward the last few days I have had back pain - in the middle part of my back 'on both sides equal' - (I don't normally have back problems, however, I have been on a rowing machine that last 7 maybe 10 days and I am wondering if this is the cause as oppose to a side effect of the lower oestrogen in my body.  Going back to words, you will see on many of my posts I have added words in brackets saying things like 'I can't think of the right word to say' or 'can't think of how to explain this'....  this sounds similar to you, I know what I want to say but the word/s will not come to me. Not so bad on here whilst typing as I can go back and alter when/if correct word comes, not so easy when in conversation and to top it all, it will normally happen if 'someone is actually listening to me' (not very often haha). I was telling this to a friend an ex-maths and science teacher, a clever friend and was surprised at what they said.... (hoping this is true, it made me feel better)... apparently the short term memory and mid-term memory is just that, it does not bother to 'store things that aren't that important' and again the mid-term is better at remembering but doesn't really bother to save all the information and give it to long term memories.... it only tends to pass memory that are worthwhile!!  This did make me feel better, but I over ran with how I related to this.... For the last week maybe two weeks I have being out walking, not far but have got out, I wrote in on the 'Walking back to Happiness' thread.  Now then, I honestly can't recall 'how many walks I have done' or how many days and .... this bothers me.  Other people would say, owww I started on the blar blar and have done a total of 'x' miles now.... well not me, it feels like its a few days and as for miles well the ladies on here suggested using an 'app' to keep track and this is what I have done. At this moment I could not tell you have far I have walked in total or for how many days!!! (it did bother me, then I recall what my friend said, we can't remember everything, plus stress and worry add to this, so for now, I am forgetting the thoughts of 'what I thought it was' (again another stress factor worrying about this).   For now, I am holding out my arms to the side and taking a deep breath in and then letting it all float out as I breath out (my late mother-in-law always said this, God Rest her beautiful Soul). I think we are all 'just to hard on ourselves - given what we have/are going through' - as Leolady rightly lets us know ... come on girls, big pants on - group hug' xxxxx

Posts.Title: Uplifting things

Posts.Content: Dearest daisyjake,  I am sorry you have found yourself joinin this group, the group that none of us wanted to join.  You are in the right place, if you have any questions or worries ask away, there is always someone listening and can offer words of advice and help.  I've just wrote down the pain killers that Snowys Mum has mentioned, it is always good to know these things. I know the coming weeks the wait will drive you mad.  Whilst I was waiting for my operation, due to my worries and concerns, my consultation put me on Letrozole, this was given as an adjuvant therapy, to treat and possible 'shrink' the BC along with minimising my worry of the risk of growth. Dependant on age and operation most ladies are put on some form of adjuvant medications with the view of suppressing any secondaries, two of the main types of tablets are Tamoxifen (given to ladies that have not had the menopause) and Letrozole (given to ladies that are in or have gone through the menopause).   I wonder if you could ask your Consultant or Breast Care Nurse if they would consider, if it would be beneficial to you, to put you on letrozole whilst you are waiting for your operation?  It is worth asking.  Sending you 'Belated Happy Birthday Greetings'. - totally agree it was a rubbish present, I think after all this is over and you have got off this roller coaster of a ride, that you plan an extra special belated birthday treat.  Offering you gently hugs xxxx
