Posts.Title: Single & Life with Cancer

Posts.Content: Hello Twinkle79 - Please get this checked.  I don't wish to worry you, you need to get this checked out 'for your own peace of mind'. I was where you was on 23rd August, 2017.  I only went to my doctor after seeing a photo/post on Facebook from a lady saying not all breast cancers are lumps - she had a dimple.  Well, I noticed when I lean forward I had a 'slight' dent on my left breast, above my nipple towards my shoulder area.  My Doctor seemed to think it looked like a 'natural crease line' - been a larger lady, my doctor did say she would refer me via the '2 week rapid access' - which, in a way I had peace of mind thinking its a 'crease line' and I'd be seen within two weeks.  The Breast Clinic was amazing, so organised. First I seen a Breast surgeon, he looked and thought it was nothing to be alarmed about, then on for a mammogram, followed by an ultra sound.  Whilst having the ultra sound the doctor took a biopsy (painless really, the worse part was the injection and that only stung). After biopsy, went back in to see Breast surgeon and he said 'well, I was not expecting this'.  I had to go back two days later for all details 'Left breast cancer, grade 1 NST, 20mm diamond ER positive.  Talk about shock. I don't want to scare you with what I have wrote and I hope and pray for you that it is a false alarm - put for peace of mind you do need to get this checked out.
Posts.Title: Newbie - do I need to get this checked?

Posts.Content: Dear Jdperry, Like the other lovely ladies have said it is a personal choice. I am large busted, if there was a magic wand, I'd of had them reduced, but would never have had the courage plus I carry a lot of weight, so thats always been the centre of my thinking - my weight. I went from choosing between a lumpectomy or a therapeutic mammoplasty (having other boob reduced to match), I was so scared at the thought, with help from here I actually turned my worry around and was, for want of better words looking forward to having operation and coming out the other side with smaller boobs. My treatment plan then completely changed, I had a lumpectomy with combined radiotherapy.   My one boob is now smaller and, if I am honest, I do prefer this one now to 'old faithful'. Would I put myself through an operation 'to even myself up', I don't think so, I'm okay with how it is and mentally I could not put myself though an operation 'out of choice', I'm to much of a chicken.  In my 'day to day' life the difference in size doesn't bother me, I don't even give it a second thought.  The time it comes into my mind is when I look at myself in the mirror (I don't to that very often as I don't like what I see and thats nothing to do with my operation hahah)  - when I look and see, I think 'are look at poor old faithful' - would I have an operation to reduce old faithful.... naarrr, I can manage with this.... I haven't got the courage. So, I've waffled on and not helped, my final thoughts for you..... Don't have the operation if it is due to comments from oncologist, if there are health reason and she said it, then that is different. ""You have to do what is best for you"" - purely for you and how you feel.   If you reman unsure either way, ask them to give you some time, time to think about it all, I am sure they can give you this. With Best Wishes xxx

Posts.Title: supply of accord (Letrozole)

Posts.Content: Dear calador, I can read your worry - you sound like I was when I first went onto letrozole.  I had worked myself up that much, it was like I was going to wake up after taking the tablet like some crazed monster. I was so scared.  Thankfully, with help and advice from the ladies in this group, I took my tablet and I am still 'me' .... as such, I do have side effects however, they are manageable.  One side effect I have at the moment is 'trigger thumb' (it came in both thumbs, however, it has worn off on the one, and I hope with time it will wear off on the other).   My new side effect is 'very achy hands' - now then, I take my tablet last thing at night and wake up in the morning with the stiff-achy hands - a few clenched fists and they come back to normal (although still trigger thumb - its locked in a straight position, funnily enough towards the evening this loosens up ever so slightly). Going off topic.  I have a couple of suggestions.   Firstly, for peace of mind, if you can stay taking your tablet I think this will help you.... regardless of brand, knowing you are taking the tablet can mentally help. Secondly, I do always wonder this, 'is it a side effect' or is it the way our body 'actually is with less oestrogen' - effecting different parts of our body at different times. Thirdly, if your doctor is prescribing a 'named brand' ie Cipla.... could he a) prescribe Femara and tell him you will take prescription to another chemist or  b) ask him if he won't do this, to prescribe you 'letrozole' on the prescription then... In the meantime you telephone various chemists and ask them what brand they supply, try the larger pharmacies. You are free to take prescription to the chemist of your choice. One thing I was told and I believe, is that when a doctor 'writes the name of a tablet' on the prescription - the pharmacy get reimbursed 'in full' because he 'has to prescribe the particular tablet'. Finally, instead of going without, even if you have a different brand for a month or so, you can look into all options during this time. If you do take a different brand you can then tell your doctor, you have tried a different brand and side effects are unbearable and would like him to prescribe the brand thats suits you (again, I think they have to do this, although I am not 100% sure, so would welcome anyone else advice/comments). A little light hearted joke.... It really is crazy the ladies on Femara behave like they belong to a secret group and have to keep there heads down and not make any false moves or eye contact, do nothing that will course anyone to notice them as they are handed over their tablets, they walk out of the drug dealers... I mean chemist, walking outside and then checking the paper bag and is it, is it, is it..... YEsssssssssss - jump for joy for another few weeks only to start the process all over again!! Sending love and hugs xxxx   (I've waffled on, so hope my reply makes sense) x
Posts.Title: supply of accord (Letrozole)

Posts.Content: Dear Cham           I really don't know how to answer this, I had a lumpectomy and had virtually no pain from the lumpectomy site, to the point I was amazed that something like this can be done, with so very little pain.  The lymph node area was a separate thing, this did hurt, not massively, when I say hurt, it stung more than hurt I suppose and was an uncomfortable type of sensation.          I would ask if you could go back and see your BC Nurse, or if possible, just turn up. Ask if they can have a look. I'd like to say after 3 weeks your pain should be getting less not more.  Your surgeon knows best and it could be nerve pain, however, it could even be an infection developing (does the area feel hot or look red, this can be a sign) or it could be an internal stitch pulling, etc.           In the meantime, did they give you any pain killers that you could take, if so, I think you should be taking them.          Please don't put up with this, no one should suffer pain however its caused.  Go and see your BC Nurse and ask for her advice xx
Posts.Title: Post lumpectomy pain

Posts.Content: Hello kargus and all you other lovelies, I've got to join in, firstly... down there, I had a few days after my operation where it felt sore, although wasn't if that makes sense, I can't think who suggested it, but, they said a little bit of olive oil can ease any soreness. Now then the phantom smell, I have answered a post on here before about my experience - I am and have been going through this the last few days, I'll come back to this, In previous times I had this type of smell that, well, I couldn't actually smell it 'if I was trying to smell it' - it was random when I breathed. Cutting a long story short (I do have problems doing this), I had a bacterial injection on my lung - this had come from me swollowing a crumb of bread and it went down the wrong way - the smell was the 'bread' breaking down - rotting I suppose and of course breathing let me smell this indescribable smell.  A course of antibiotics cleared this up along with over 4 years of daily agonsing acid-reflux - the antibiotics cleared this up (and thankfully, it is still at bay). Now then, has I say, I have had this the last few days and was waiting for the back pain (by shoulder blade to confirm if I'd done the same).... nothing.  So, after a lot of thought this time I had put it down to the remains of a very bad cold back in January. I was thinking it could be still sitting on my chest - since taking letrozole the mucus I have is very thick and hard to move.  So either this or I am wondering if it could be a side effect from one of my Glucosamine tablets (not long changed brand).   The thing that gets me with mine.... it is a smell that you can't explain, it is like burning - although the other day, I said it was like a 'chemical' type of smell, the sort you smell in a dry cleaners shop - just so unusual. Regarding your results, I have to agree with the other ladies.  Firstly, they must look at everyones results straight away, within no time, because imagine if some one does have a serious diagnosis - they sit on results 'till they get around to them'.  So, I think the actual results getting back to your doctors this quick is the norm for that hospital.  I would hope that your Doctor would phone contact you and ask you to go in - if it was something serious.  Your doctor writing asking you to make a 'routine' appointment - could be just as it says to talk about your results and see how you are getting on.   The thing is no matter what any of us write and how plausible our words are - you will worry, it is our make up, its what we do best. I am sorry you are feeling like this and as much as I'd like to ease your worry - I know, I'd be the same.  What I will say is, you are the same as you was the other day and no amount of worrying is going to change anything - it is what it is (that sounds hard, I don't mean for it to be).  What I'm trying to say - worrying isn't going to help you - its just going to make you worse.  What ever it is you will get through this - you have us all hear and reading between the lines, try and take comfort from what everyone has said. Thinking of you xxx

Posts.Title: Lumpectomy concerns

Posts.Content: Hello Callib - Welcome to the Group that none of us wanted to join. I was put on Letrozole 'before' my lumpectomy, this was whilst treatment was being arranged, I was put on it for 'peace of mind' for myself.  I was worried about 'it' growing whilst I looked into treatment.  I think it was for around 3 maybe 4 weeks and it did shrink it a little whilst arranging treatment.   But, being honest totally honest, I would rather 'get it out' earlier - than to wait for it to shrink with tablets for a smaller incision site.  After all the operation would be the same, if you are having a 'lumpectomy' - you would still be having lumpectomy.   I personally think, if you can have the surgery sooner - the sooner the better mentally for you.  If they have other reasons, like they 'need' you to have tablets to shrink then this puts a different light on it, if it is 'to shrink' for smaller removal - well sooner the better is my view for you both mentally and to get on with recovery. Sending love and hugs xxxx
Posts.Title: Neo adjuvant hormone therapy ( tamoxifen before surgery )

Posts.Content: Dear Emily (UniqueBird), I am sorry you find yourself here, but, you have come to the right place.  There are a lovely punch of 'Fruit Loops' as the like to be know, or even 'Rif Raff' - all come on and offer help and advice at various times of the day or night.  The knowledge these ladies know is amazing and I am sure others will be along soon. I had my lumpectomy back in October (2017) along with SNB and to be honest, I had very little pain at the lumpectomy operation site, however, the SNB area was sore in a stinging type of way. You and your body have gone thought a lot, never mind your saying it's a minor operation, I thought this, until the ladies on here put me wise, it is a big operation, your body as so much to deal with, even the side effects of the anaesthetic, even this effects the body and takes time to come out of your system. Please be kind to yourself, you have gone through a lot and possibly now the reality of it all is sinking in.... sinking in, when you are now on your way to starting your recovery - it all happens so fast. Getting back to your pain, you must make sure you do the exercises you have been told about, these are very important, to keep everything free moving. Please keep an eye on how it feels, if you still feel uncomfortable then contact your BCN or even call in to see them.   Keep an eye on the area for any redness or if it feels hot or hot to the touch - as these can be signs of an infection. (with how hot the last few days if the area as been hot and sweating you need to keep your eye on it). Sending you {{{{Big Hugs}}}} - You will get through this - Plus, you've found us now (Heaven help you ;) I hope you've dropped back off to sleep - Nighty Night xxx
Posts.Title: SNB post op nerve pain and dragging

Posts.Content: Hello kathleen37, Deep breaths, deep breaths, calm down, this can't happen over night, but.... you are working on it and this is the main thing. First, I'm not a doctor, my thoughts are my own...... I am over weight, I have been for a number of years, I have lumpectomy October 2017.  I was told and I also read that oestrogen can be made by the fat cells in our body.  So, I was right, got to do something about this..... it didn't happen.  I take Letrozole and had every intention to loose weight.  Far easier to say than do, I was still in shock with all that had happened and I guess I was comforting eating, I needed lots of comfort, plus I'm only 5'2" (if I was 8'6" I would be the right weight for my height, haha).   I wanted to loose weight, the one consultant even said to encourage me, lets see how much you can loose when you come back - hmmm 'none' :(  Fast forward 12 months, I go for my 1st Year mammogram, check up etc.  I have a blood test, my results come back, so many results 'out of range' - I am in the diabetic range, my liver results (Gamma GT) out of range, Triglycerides out of range. My HbA1c is 68 (range is 20-42) over 42 is diabetic...... I was floored, this totally floored me, I had gone through the BC and then this!!!   I was told to visit my own Doctor have bloods done again and ask for a liver scan!  I was going to post on here for help, I kept putting it off.  The shock was amazing, I have used this to 'try' to turn every thing around.  I gave myself 3 months (the Hb1Ac only changes every 3 months - its like window to our body for the last three months).  So, I gave myself 3 months to 'try' to change things around.  I have cut down on carbs (no bread now), I am 'sort of doing Low Carbs/High Fat' - I am walking (originally suggested the Walking back to Happiness thread to Leolady), I am now walking around 1 to 3 miles a day - most days!  I have lost nearly 2 stone. So my thoughts are, loosing 'any' weight has got to be good.  The less fat we have, the less fat we have to make the oestrogen. Carbs turn into sugar.... apparently, 'C' loves sugar, so, by reducing the carbs, this will reduce levels available to turn into sugar. Fats don't turned to sugar. Carbs do. Maybe "that going low carb can give you a huge boost of oestrogen to begin with " <<<< maybe this is actually using the oestrogen stored in the fat cells - or maybe it is pulling it out of the stores ?? Just a thought. My last thoughts are, we can't turn this around 'over night', the main thing is we are taking steps to do this, ANY step forward to reduce weight is for the best.  Reducing carbs = reducing sugar.  This can only be a good thing. As I say, my thoughts, still check it out with your Nurse etc.  The main thing is by loosing weight - this will reduce fat stores and if oestrogen can be made or is made within fat cells, the more we reduce these the better. Hope this helps a little xx

Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: This might help too.... I had wide local excision, I had no visible stitches on the outside of my body, however, I can't remember how long after operation this happened, only a week or maybe two... it was at the 'one' end of the operation site, I thought it was a small blister, then I thought it was tiny scab, so ignored it, however it felt rough to the point where I sort of kept touching it, then low and behold I could see a little bit of clear nylon (I imagine, similar to nylon fishing line). I phoned my consultant and also posted on here, I had what is known as 'spitting a stitch'.  The body is trying to get the foreign object out of the body.  My consultant said so long as there was not itching, redness or soreness all would be okay and it would work its way out  It did, the tiny bit of nylon over the coming days became a little longer and a little longer, till the one day I was touching it and it came off/out (with a tiny bit of help from me) it was a strange twisted shape, which I was a tiny knot.   I have photos, however, I don't think anyone would want to see them If it is a 'spitting stitch', it will work its way out naturally. I hope this helps a little - Good idea to see what you GP thinks. xxx
Posts.Title: Post op complications

Posts.Content: If the mountain seems to big.... i love this Violetsniff - these ‘thought of the day’ are really inspiring.  I believe we put a lot of pressure on ourselves, that we don’t give ourselves the true credit we deserve for how well we try to cope and try to mange.  When I had my lumpectomy, I remember one Fruit Loop saying to me ‘you’ve had major surgery’!! - I’d never classed it as ‘major surgery’. This made me stop and think how well I had done (the same person that hates and keeps putting off going to the dentist). Sending love and hugs xxxx
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: I felt I needed to reply to you..... definitely not wicked, I think these situations come to the best of us (well we are), to save others that couldn't manage with such situations.  (I do need to convince myself of this though, I do think why should kind people get such things, when there are so many cruel people in the world sailing on by with not a care or a worry). I don't know what to say, the waiting is the worst part of all this along with processing it in our mind and how we deal with it, then slowly comes the strength.  The liver is an amazing organ and one that can regenerate.  My dear Dad had tumours in 90% of his liver and we didn't even know, at this time he was living a normal life. CrazyKnitter and puzzler you are walking a path many of us fear every day, we always need to remember how far treatment has come and how fast treatments are changing; there is so much they can do to help and heal the liver.   There are groups on this forum for secondaries that might offer ideas and help.  Keep posting here too, we are here for you and will offer help and advice if we can, most of all we can offer support, comfort, laughs - you name it will we be here for you. Sending you hugs and love xxx

Posts.Title: Caption Competition

Posts.Content: Hello Ladies, I to am on Letrozole.  I can say I have not had too many effects, the main one, which I am praying will ease off as quick as it came on is 'trigger thumb' in both thumbs. I totally agree with all that Taralou has said.  I would just like to add this thought..... Could these aches and pains be 'side effects' or....... could these aches and pains actually be how our bodies feel having 'less oestrogen' ?? Would you still feel like this after changing to another type of tablet, or to a different brand? Could the various tablets take out oestrogen in different ways and each of our bodies feel different. Maybe it's not a side effect, maybe each of our bodies each react different depending how much the tablet has lessened the oestrogen.. Just a thought  xx
Posts.Title: Has anyone stopped taking letrozole and switched to other aromatase...

Posts.Content: This is where the fast roller coaster ride has stopped at the platform and its your time to get off.  We can never go back to the person we was before all this.  To go through what you have and expect to be told, thats it, all is done now and you walk off happy and 'norma' just isn't the case.  It takes it out of you,  you have days when you will wobble along with days where you nearly forget about it.  It is just so horrible when you want the support of people that are the closest to us - yet these are the very people saying 'its gone now, come on'!! I do think it is personal to us, only others on here that have gone through all this will understand how vulnerable we feel. Take each day as it comes, you are going to have down days, remember 'this is normal' - I'm still coming to terms with my lifelong friend 'not wanting anything to do with me' and says 'they have a lot going on and will be in touch soon'...... this from a friend I would of walked on hot coals for, hmmm sadly, lessons to be learnt (on my part). Sending Love and Hugs xxxx
